title-group.article-title: Risk Factors of Subtalar Arthroereisis for Progressive Collapsing Foot Deformity: A Retrospective Analysis of 236 Cases

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2025 The Author(s). Orthopaedic Surgery published by Tianjin Hospital and John Wiley & Sons Australia, Ltd.

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non‐commercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

sec.title: Purpose
sec.p: Although subtalar arthroereisis (SA) with HyProCure is increasingly utilized for progressive collapsing foot deformity (PCFD), evidence regarding risk factors for complications remains limited. This study aimed to analyze the influencing factors and correlations of sinus tarsi pain and implant removal in PCFD patients after SA utilizing the HyProCure device.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A retrospective study was conducted involving 223 patients (236 ft) diagnosed with PCFD who underwent SA from June 2015 to June 2023. General data and surgical data such as patient gender, age, body mass index (BMI), surgical side, any adjunctive surgeries, length of stay, HyProCure size, and HyProCure depth were collected. Complications were also recorded. Statistical analysis included normality assessment, inter‐group comparisons (t‐tests for normal quantitative data, Mann–Whitney U for non‐normal data, and chi‐square for categorical variables). Spearman correlation analyzed factors associated with sinus tarsi pain and implant removal. Binary logistic regression identified risk factors.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: From 2015 to 2023, a total of 60 cases with sinus tarsi pain, with an incidence rate of 25.42%. Spearman correlation analysis showed that sinus tarsi pain was positively correlated with BMI (r = 0.159, p = 0.014), length of stay (r = 0.165, p = 0.011), and HyProCure depth (r = 0.501, p < 0.01). HyProCure removal was positively correlated with HyProCure depth (r = 0.521, p < 0.01) and sinus tarsi pain (r = 0.700, p < 0.01). In the analysis of sinus tarsi pain, the primary risk factor in patients with PCFD was identified as length of stay (OR = 1.456, 95% CI 1.113–1.904) and HyProCure depth (OR = 2.156, 95% CI 1.690–2.750), both of which were statistically significant (p < 0.05). Among the cases of sinus tarsi pain, 36 patients underwent HyProCure removal, leading to an incidence rate of 15.25%. Regarding the removal of HyProCure, the primary risk factor identified was HyProCure depth (OR = 2.531, 95% CI 1.849–3.463), which was statistically significant (p < 0.05). In particular, no significant correlation was observed between HyProCure size and sinus tarsi pain or implant removal (p > 0.05).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In patients with PCFD, length of stay was correlated with the incidence of sinus tarsi pain. Additionally, HyProCure depth was linked to both the incidence of sinus tarsi pain and HyProCure removal. Our research suggests that the prognosis is better for PCFD patients with a shorter length of stay and a reduced HyProCure depth.
Level of Evidence: Level III, Retrospective Comparative Study.

abstract.p: The risk factor of sinus tarsi pain in patients with PCFD was identified as length of stay and HyProCure depth. Among the cases of HyProCure removal, the risk factor identified was HyProCure depth. These will provide a research basis for the influencing factors of sinus tarsi pain and HyProCure removal.

institution-wrap.institution: Science and Technology Commission of Shanghai Municipality
Shanghai Municipal Commission of Economy and Informatization

p.mixed-citation: S.Fu, J.Wang, C.Wang, C.Wu, S.Zhang, and Z.Shi, “Risk Factors of Subtalar Arthroereisis for Progressive Collapsing Foot Deformity: A Retrospective Analysis of 236 Cases,” Orthopaedic Surgery17, no. 9 (2025): 2662–2669, 10.1111/os.70148.PMC1240485840776555

fn.p: Funding: This work was supported by the Science and Technology Commission of Shanghai Municipality (23015820500, 24Y32800100) and the Shanghai Municipal Commission of Economy and Informatization (23SHS03600).
Shaoling Fu and Jiazheng Wang contributed equally to this study.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Adult acquired flatfoot deformity (AAFD), also known as posterior tibialis tendon dysfunction (PTTD) [1]. Initially, it was widely accepted that the primary etiology of AAFD stemmed from degenerative alterations in the posterior tibial tendon. However, as research progressed, reports suggested that the occurrence of flatfoot is not entirely related to PTTD, and the Johnson and Strom classification inadequately captured the disease's complexity. Isolated subtalar joint dislocations, though rare, also represent a critical contributor to acquired flatfoot. Medial subtalar dislocations can disrupt the talocalcaneal and talonavicular joints, leading to valgus malalignment and arch collapse [2]. Furthermore, repetitive microtraumas may be caused by activities such as volleyball or basketball, necessitating an understanding of injury mechanisms [3]. In response, Myerson introduced a novel classification in 2020 that categorizes flatfoot as progressive collapsing foot deformity (PCFD), based on foot flexibility and the specific locations of deformities [4]. This classification asserts that PCFD is a three‐dimensional complex deformity characterized by significant inter‐joint relationships, comprising two deformity types and five location categories (A‐E) [4]. It emphasizes a detailed description of foot deformities, facilitating a more precise evaluation of complex flatfoot presentations, which aligns more closely with clinical observations.

Surgical measures are recommended for patients when conservative treatments fail to yield satisfactory outcomes in PCFD [5]. Minimally invasive surgeries such as subtalar arthroereisis (SA) have gained traction, with devices like HyProCure device (GraMedica, Macomb, MI, USA) and expansion screw offering joint‐preserving alternatives to traditional methods [6]. SA with HyProCure devices presents several advantages in the treatment of PCFD. It corrects flatfoot deformity while preserving joint integrity through the application of HyProCure device. Compared to traditional surgical methods, SA is less intrusive, maintains joint function, and allows for the removal of the HyProCure device without negatively affecting the subtalar joint [4]. Some reports indicate a high level of patient satisfaction following SA, positioning it as a viable surgical option for adult patients [7, 8, 9].

Currently, there is a limited number of reports addressing the influencing factors. The main issue in this research involves the risk factors associated with sinus tarsi pain and HyProCure removal in PCFD patients. Consequently, this study aims to investigate (i) the risk factors of sinus tarsi pain; and (ii) the risk factors of HyProCure removal.

sec.title: Study Design and Setting
sec.p: A retrospective analysis of clinical data was conducted on 223 cases (236 ft) of PCFD patients who were admitted from June 2015 to June 2023. All patients underwent SA.

sec.title: Participants/Study Subjects
sec.p: The inclusion criteria were as follows: (1) all patients were flexible PCFD I A‐B stage; (2) age between 19 and 75 years; (3) failed to respond to 6 months of conservative treatment preoperatively, had poor plantar flexion strength on the affected side, continued to experience foot and ankle pain, and discomfort after walking; and (4) complete follow‐up data were available.

The exclusion criteria were as follows: (1) rigid or neurogenic flatfoot patients; (2) severe joint restriction; (3) severe peripheral vascular disease, autoimmune disease, or poorly controlled diabetes; (4) severe rheumatoid arthritis, gouty arthritis; (5) severe heart or lung function impairment; (6) inability to cooperate due to mental illness; and (7) history of trauma or surgery to the affected foot.

This retrospective study included all consecutive PCFD patients meeting inclusion criteria from June 2015 to June 2023 at our institution. No formal power analysis was performed due to the retrospective nature. The sample size was determined by the availability of complete clinical and follow‐up data during this period. Patients were systematically screened against inclusion/exclusion criteria by two surgeons to ensure homogeneity.

sec.title: Selection of HyProCure Sizes
sec.p: HyProCure size was determined intraoperatively. Following the implantation of either a larger or smaller sizer, a motion assessment of the talotarsal joint (TTJ) was conducted until a normal range of tarsal motion, ideally between 3° and 5°, was achieved. To evaluate TTJ pronation, a consistent dorsal force is applied to the necks of the fourth and fifth metatarsals. Repeated assessment was performed to confirm that the implanted device was of the appropriate size. The threaded section of HyProCure should align with the opening of sinus tarsi. Intraoperative fluoroscopy verified the accurate placement of HyProCure.

sec.title: Data Collection and Evaluation Indicators
sec.p: In this study, general data of patients were selected, including general data (sex, age, and body mass index (BMI)) and surgical data (surgical side, whether combined with other surgeries, length of stay, HyProCure size, and HyProCure depth). Other surgeries combined include achilles tendon lengthening, calcaneus osteotomy, Cotton osteotomy, accessory navicular bone excision, scarf osteotomy, spring ligament repair, and arthroscopic lateral ankle ligament repair. HyProCure depth is defined as the measurement from the center of HyProCure to the longitudinal talar bisection line along the weightbearing anteroposterior X‐ray, regardless of whether its position was deep or shallow (Figure 1).

caption.p: HyProCure depth on weightbearing anteroposterior X‐ray. (a) longitudinal talar bisection line; (b) HyProCure center.

sec.p: For patients who underwent a second surgery to remove HyProCure due to unrelieved tarsal sinus pain, the patients' data were also recorded.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: SPSS 26.0 statistical software (IBM, Armonk, NY, USA) was used for data analysis by the authors. The normality of the data was assessed using the Shapiro–Wilk test. Normally distributed data were presented as mean ± standard deviation (x¯±s), and non‐normally distributed data were described using median (M (Q1, Q3)). For normally distributed quantitative data, conduct inter‐group comparisons using t‐tests. For non‐normally distributed quantitative data, use Mann–Whitney U tests for inter‐group comparisons. Chi‐square tests are employed for categorical variables. p < 0.05 is considered statistically significant.

Spearman correlation analysis was performed on all the selected factors to evaluate the correlation between each factor and sinus tarsi pain and HyProCure removal before the analysis of influencing factors. Then, an univariate analysis was performed for all the selected factors. General data and surgical data were used as independent variables. Variables with p < 0.1 in the results are considered meaningful variables. Then, a binary logistic regression model was constructed to analyze the multiple factors. The results of the multi‐factor analysis showed that p < 0.05 was statistically significant.

sec.title: General Results
sec.p: This study included 223 patients (236 ft), with 71 males (80 ft) and 151 females (156 ft) (Figure 2). Patients' ages ranged from 19 to 75 years, with a BMI of 23.20 ± 3.64 kg/m2.

caption.p: A 46‐year‐old female patient was treated with SA. (A) The patient who had right PCFD and hallux valgus took weightbearing lateral and anteroposterior X‐ray, indicating that the angles of the foot were abnormal; (B) Preoperative general photo; (C,D) the foot weightbearing lateral and anteroposterior X‐ray and general view showed the deformity correction at 24‐month follow‐up.

sec.title: Complications
sec.p: As for complications, no intraoperative complications occurred. There were a total of 65 cases of complications at the last follow‐up, with a complication rate of 27.54%. Sixty cases (25.42%) of sinus tarsi pain were documented, of which 24 patients felt symptomatic relief after conservative treatment. Conversely, 36 patients (15.25%) required the removal of HyProCure due to the ineffectiveness of conservative management. Among these patients, the median time to removal was 21.33 months (range 12–67 months). Post‐removal, 100% reported pain alleviation.

Other complications included one case of achilles tendon tension, which required a secondary surgery for tendon lengthening, with good postoperative recovery; one case of poor wound healing, which improved after dressing changes and wound cleaning; and three cases of muscle strength decline, which returned to normal following physical therapy, systematic exercise, and lower limb strength training. There were no postoperative wound infections or peripheral vascular nerve injuries.

sec.title: Correlation Analysis
sec.p: Sex, age, BMI, surgical side, whether combined with other surgeries, length of stay, and HyProCure size were analyzed. Spearman correlation analysis showed that sinus tarsi pain was positively correlated with BMI (r = 0.159, p = 0.014), length of stay (r = 0.165, p = 0.011), and HyProCure depth (r = 0.501, p < 0.01). HyProCure removal was positively correlated with HyProCure depth (r = 0.521, p < 0.01) and sinus tarsi pain (r = 0.700, p < 0.01) (Figure 3).

caption.p: Spearman correlation analysis of each factor.

sec.title: Multivariate Analysis of Sinus Tarsi Pain
sec.p: In patients with sinus tarsi pain, univariate analysis took the occurrence of sinus tarsi pain as the dependent variable, and patients' general data and surgical data as independent variables. Statistical results showed that the patient's age, BMI, length of stay, and HyProCure depth were statistically significant (p < 0.1), while sex, surgical side, whether combined with other surgeries, and HyProCure size were not statistically significant (p > 0.1) (Table 1). The major predicting factors (age, BMI, length of stay, and HyProCure depth) with p < 0.1 in univariate analysis were included in multivariate analysis. The results indicated that length of stay (OR = 1.456, 95% CI 1.113–1.904) and HyProCure depth (OR = 2.156, 95% CI 1.690–2.750) were statistically significant (p < 0.05) and served as the primary risk factors influencing the incidence of sinus tarsi pain in PCFD patients (Figure 4).

caption.p: Univariate analysis of sinus tarsi pain.
Multivariate analysis of sinus tarsi pain and HyProCure removal.

sec.title: Multivariate Analysis of HyProCure Removal
sec.p: For patients undergoing secondary surgery to remove HyProCure, an univariate analysis was conducted with general data and surgical data. The results indicated that BMI and HyProCure depth had statistical significance (P < 0.1), while sex, age, surgical side, whether combined with other surgeries, and HyProCure size showed no statistical significance (p > 0.1) (Table 2). The major predicting factors (BMI and HyProCure depth) were used to construct a multivariate analysis. The findings revealed that HyProCure depth was the primary risk factor for HyProCure removal in PCFD patients. HyProCure depth (OR = 2.531, 95% CI 1.849–3.463) showed statistical significance (p < 0.05) (Figure 3).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Complications of SA utilizing HyProCure include persistent pain, overcorrection or undercorrection, postoperative infection and inflammatory reactions, peroneal spasm, muscle strength decline, and other adverse reactions. Among these, persistent pain localized in the sinus tarsi area is the most prevalent [10]. Potential etiological factors for sinus tarsi pain encompass undercorrection, overcorrection, interactions between the implant and the posterior subtalar joint surface, as well as soft tissue irritation [11, 12]. Initial conservative treatments may include customized orthotic insoles, functional exercises, and corticosteroid injections aimed at symptomatic relief. With these, some patients may experience alleviation or disappearance of symptoms. These interventions may lead to symptom alleviation or resolution in some patients. However, if pain persists without improvement, consideration should be given to secondary surgery for implant removal or reevaluation for revision surgery.

sec.title: Risk Factors of Sinus Tarsi Pain
sec.p: Certain studies indicate that the size of HyProCure may influence the incidence of postoperative sinus tarsi pain [13, 14], while other investigations report no significant correlation [15]. In this study, we found that in patients with PCFD, the primary risk factors for sinus tarsi pain are not related to the size of HyProCure but rather the length of stay and HyProCure depth. Although the power of suggestion from the physician or staff that the subject is doing well is enough to create a slant toward doing better. Notably, an extended length of stay correlates with an increased incidence of sinus tarsi pain, as patients may perceive their postoperative condition as suboptimal, which can instill a fear of ambulation or participation in rehabilitation exercises. Also, our finding suggests that patients with a longer distance from the center of the implant to the longitudinal talar bisection line had a higher incidence of sinus tarsi pain. Previous studies also suggested that implant depth may be a contributing factor [15, 16]. Although no direct correlation between HyProCure size and sinus tarsi pain has been established, careful consideration should be given to implant size selection to prevent complications such as excessive implant distance leading to sinus tarsi penetration, undercorrection, or overcorrection. Therefore, in performing SA for PCFD patients, we advocate for the selection of a smaller HyProCure over a larger one when both options are available to mitigate the risk of complications.

BMI is recognized as a factor for sinus tarsi pain after implant displacement [17]. Some studies reported that patients with higher BMI tend to experience a higher incidence of sinus tarsi pain postoperatively [18]. Conversely, other research has suggested a lack of correlation between BMI and sinus tarsi pain [15]. This study revealed that while BMI demonstrated a correlation with sinus tarsi pain in univariate analysis, it did not exhibit a significant association in multivariate analysis, suggesting that BMI is not a primary risk factor for sinus tarsi pain in PCFD patients. In addition, our findings indicate that the presence of adjunctive surgery does not constitute a risk factor for sinus tarsi pain in PCFD patients. Agnew et al. [8] proposed that this may be due to the frequent combination of adjunctive surgeries in PCFD patients undergoing SA, which may lead to higher rates of complications and adverse outcomes as reported in prior studies.

sec.title: Risk Factors of HyProCure Removal
sec.p: In the case of HyProCure removal, there exists a divergence of opinion among researchers regarding the significance of implant size in PCFD patients [14, 19]. While some studies dismissed size as a pertinent factor, others advocated for its relevance. Our study indicates a lack of correlation between HyProCure size and HyProCure removal in PCFD patients, with no instances of secondary surgery aimed at altering the size in this study. Reviewing past literature also supports that the size of the implant does not inherently dictate removal outcomes [19]. Several factors may contribute to the decision to remove HyProCure, including patient‐reported symptoms, implant position, and postoperative recovery. In this study, we found that in PCFD patients, the primary risk factor for sinus tarsi pain leading to HyProCure removal is HyProCure depth. Specifically, patients exhibiting a longer distance from the center of the implant to the longitudinal talar bisection line demonstrated a 153.1% increased likelihood of developing HyProCure removal.

Notably, HyProCure depth is a risk factor for both sinus tarsi pain and HyProCure removal. As HyProCure depth increases, the risk of sinus tarsi pain and the risk of HyProCure removal also increase. Thus, in the context of SA, it is imperative not only to ensure stable articulation and recovery of foot alignment post‐HyProCure implantation but also to meticulously align the screw tail with the ostium of the sinus tarsi during the surgery.

This alignment should aim to position the center of HyProCure as closely as possible to the longitudinal bisection line of the talus, thereby mitigating postoperative pain and reducing the rates of HyProCure removal in PCFD patients. It is important to note that the severity of sinus tarsi pain and its association with HyProCure removal may be influenced by individual pain tolerance, postoperative symptomatic management, and proactive functional rehabilitation, necessitating further case studies to validate the significance of these factors.

Moreover, this study analyzed other factors and found that the patient's sex, age, surgical side, and whether combined surgery are not independent factors for sinus tarsi pain or HyProCure removal in PCFD patients. The results of this study are similar to those reported in previous studies [19].

Consequently, through the follow‐up, preliminary conclusions can be drawn regarding the incidence of sinus tarsi pain and the risk of HyProCure removal in PCFD patients, allowing for the development of personalized postoperative treatment strategies aimed at enhancing the efficacy of SA, preventing postoperative complications, optimizing patient satisfaction, and improving patient prognosis.

In cases of severe, non‐reducible deformities or failed joint‐preserving procedures, hindfoot arthrodesis remains a definitive salvage option. In a previous study on minimally invasive tibiotalocalcaneal arthrodesis, fusion procedures achieve stable alignment and pain relief in > 90% of patients, albeit at the cost of subtalar joint mobility [20]. For advanced PCFD with rigid deformities, arthrodesis is often indicated.

sec.title: Strengths and Limitations
sec.p: This study is one of the few analyses examining the factors influencing SA in PCFD patients, so as to investigate and elucidate the correlation between various patient data and the occurrence of sinus tarsi pain and HyProCure removal. However, we acknowledge that this study has limitations, and its results should be understood with these limitations in mind. First, this research is a retrospective, single‐center investigation. It is subject to biases inherent to such designs, including incomplete data collection, reliance on historical records, and inability to control for confounding variables. Prospective studies with predefined protocols for imaging and follow‐up are needed to validate these findings. Second, there may be other significant factors not included in the binary logistic regression model; thus, considering these additional factors could potentially alter our results. Third, the lack of standardized postoperative imaging protocols also restricted our ability to correlate clinical results with radiographic correction, a critical aspect of deformity surgery evaluation. This study did not analyze postoperative radiographic parameters due to inconsistent imaging follow‐up. Future work should incorporate standardized radiographic assessments to correlate clinical outcomes with anatomical correction. Fourth, this study did not perform threshold analyses to determine optimal cut‐offs. Future prospective studies should validate these thresholds and explore potential interactions with BMI or other confounders.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In conclusion, the length of stay was correlated with the incidence of sinus tarsi pain in PCFD patients. The depth of HyProCure was associated with both the prevalence of sinus tarsi pain and the necessity for HyProCure removal. Our research suggests that minimizing HyProCure depth and reducing the length of stay are associated with improved clinical outcomes. While these results are derived from observed data distributions, statistical validation through prospective studies is necessary to confirm their predictive utility. Future research should focus on conducting multi‐center, prospective studies, and further exploration of the relationship between clinical variables and the underlying mechanisms of PCFD is essential.

sec.title: Author Contributions
sec.p: Z.S. and S.F. conceptualized the study. S.F. and J.W. reviewed the literature and designed the figure and table. C.W., C.W., and S.Z. collected patients' information and performed the statistical analysis. S.F. drafted the manuscript. S.F. and Z.S. revised the manuscript. All authors read and approved the final version.

sec.title: Ethics Statement
sec.p: The study was approved by the Ethics Committee of Shanghai Sixth People's Hospital Affiliated to Shanghai Jiao Tong University (2023‐KY‐005(K)). The confidentiality of patient information was protected. The study was conducted in compliance with the Helsinki Declaration.

sec.title: Consent
sec.p: The authors have nothing to report.

sec.title: Conflicts of Interest
sec.p: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors have nothing to report.

sec.title: Data Availability Statement
sec.p: Data sharing not applicable to this article as no datasets were generated or analysed during the current study.
